title: "The Martian" is a triumph of science fiction
summary: The Martian surface is an extreme environment: the temperature fluctuates wildly, the CO2 in the air is unbreathable, the UV is intense, and there’s no water. The only way humans could survive on Mars is if they had enough supplies to last for the rest of their lives, along with a way to communicate with Earth. The challenges of living on Mars tell us something valuable about ourselves: we’re resilient, creative, and curious. When faced with a challenge, we don’t give up: we find a way of solving it.

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Ridley Scott\u2019s new movie, The Martian, is based on a novel of the same name by Andy Weir. It\u2019s about an astronaut called Mark Watney who gets stranded on Mars after his crewmates think he\u2019s dead and leave without him. This might seem as just another case of annoying Hollywood over-simplification: after all, we get so many bioengineered super-geniuses with computer uplink implants that they can become trapped in remote locations via their own stupidity. But there\u2019s more to it than that.
In both book and film, the humanity of Watney comes out in everything he does to survive: logical thinking (how can I eat this potato again?), ingenuity (I need water; how do I distill it from our CO2 filters), courage (explore the abandoned outpost), and compassion (contact my family). He also has a lot of fun with his predicament, cracking jokes through his video log and even going disco.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

content.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"A brief primer on orbital mechanics"),mdx("p",null,"When a spaceship leaves Earth, it doesn\u2019t leave under its own power. Instead, it gets a free ride from the gravity of the Earth. As the Earth rotates, this gravity pulls the ship off in the direction of the east. If the ship travels fast enough, it can get beyond the Earth\u2019s orbit. If the ship has enough velocity to overcome the Earth\u2019s gravity, it will go into a heliocentric orbit. If it travels around the sun and gets far enough away from the Earth, it can then be captured by the gravity of Mars. Once captured by Mars, it will travel in an elliptical orbit around the planet."),mdx("h2",null,"Why staying on Mars is a terrible idea"),mdx("p",null,"The Martian surface is an extreme environment: the temperature fluctuates wildly, the CO2 in the air is unbreathable, the UV is intense, and there\u2019s no water. The only way humans could survive on Mars is if they had enough supplies to last for the rest of their lives, along with a way to communicate with Earth."),mdx("p",null,"Suppose we could send someone to Mars with enough supplies to last for their whole lives. Then the rest of us would have to survive without them. So we would have to give up all our valuable international relationships and economic ties; we would have to abandon our entire way of life and start again."),mdx("h2",null,"You can\u2019t breathe the air"),mdx("p",null,"As we saw above, the Martian atmosphere is unbreathable. Astronauts have tried wearing oxygen masks, but they could only survive on the surface for 30 minutes or less. If Watney is breathing oxygen from a tank, he will have to be very careful where he goes and what he does \u2013 especially with his CO2 filters. He can only get away with these devices because of the low gravity and low CO2 content in the Martian atmosphere."),mdx("h2",null,"The sunlight is too dim"),mdx("p",null,"The sunlight on Mars is about 38% as strong as it is on Earth. This is barely enough for plants to synthesize food via photosynthesis. And it\u2019s not enough to power the solar panels that Watney uses to charge his batteries and run his communications equipment. As a result, Watney can\u2019t use the solar panels to produce oxygen, which is a shame because there\u2019s no CO2 on Mars for him to breathe."),mdx("h2",null,"There\u2019s barely any metal"),mdx("p",null,"Of course, if you could grow enough food to sustain a colony on Mars, you could also smelt enough metal to build a radio telescope. While we can\u2019t grow enough food on Mars, we could build a radio telescope: it would take a couple of decades, but we could do it."),mdx("h2",null,"The soil is toxic (and there\u2019s no organic food)"),mdx("p",null,"The top layer of the Martian soil is full of perchlorate, a chemical that is both toxic and explosive. If you try to grow food with perchlorate in the soil, it will poison the crops. If you try to feed the crops perchlorate, it will explode."),mdx("h2",null,"Summing up"),mdx("p",null,"The Martian gives us a glimpse of how difficult it would be to survive on Mars. If we ever send a manned mission, the astronauts will have to bring enough resources to last for the rest of their lives. They will have to carefully avoid poisonous soil, low light levels, and the unbreathable atmosphere. And they will have to overcome the challenge of communicating with Earth."),mdx("p",null,"But the challenges of living on Mars tell us something valuable about ourselves: we\u2019re resilient, creative, and curious. When we\u2019re faced with a challenge, we don\u2019t give up: we find a way to solve it."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"As hip-hop continues to shed its once-maligned reputation and become increasingly popular, we\u2019ve seen a related boom in mainstream rap music. More than ever before, people are listening to and talking about rappers. But with so much of the genre becoming commodified and predictable, it can be difficult for new artists to stand out among the noise. Fortunately, just because most popular rap fails to break any molds doesn\u2019t mean that the genre is completely devoid of creative talent. In fact, there are a number of rappers who have been working hard to maintain their integrity while still appealing to a larger audience. If you\u2019re ready to put on your dancing shoes and get out on the floor with one of these 10 amazing rappers who will make you want to dance:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: A-Trak's 'in My Feelings' Is a Summer Bop You Need in Your Life
Bts's 'Love Yourself: Tear' Is a Triumph

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In a world where every band is a boy band, BTS stands out. The Korean sextet has made a name for itself as not just another boy band but one that plays its own instruments and has choreographed dance routines that are so intricate they sometimes require special stage lighting.
Armed with these weapons, BTS has twice cracked the top 10 on the Billboard 200 album chart with its Love Yourself series. And the latest installment of this series \u2014 which doubles as its sixth EP \u2014 is no exception.
Furthermore, it\u2019s the strongest of the bunch.
It\u2019s impossible to talk about BTS without mentioning their massive following beyond Korea: Vivid, obsessive ARMYs (as they call them) who follow their every move and buy everything associated with them. This is why many people assume they are only famous because of social media and pandering ads (which is true). However, anyone who listens to their music will tell you that they deserve all this success. \u201CLove Yourself: Tear\u201D proves it once again.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "Birdman" Is a Darkly Comic Meditation on Fame and Ego
Beach House's '7' Is a Dreamy Masterpiece
Charlie Puth's 'Voicenotes' Is a Solid Effort

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:t,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Charlie Puth has been on a roll lately, with three top 40 hits in the last two years. He\u2019s also worked with some pretty big names (including one we\u2019ll get to shortly). Now, he\u2019s back with another new album, titled \u201CVoicenotes.\u201D It\u2019s a solid effort that shows growth and maturity, as well as keeping Puth\u2019s fun and lighthearted style.
At its core, Voicenotes is an acoustic pop album. However, it goes deeper than just putting electric guitars aside; these songs are stripped right down to the bare bones. There\u2019s still plenty of production value\u2014especially on the third track\u2014but it feels like Puth made a conscious decision not to hide behind anything.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
